Award.AwardTitle: The Ecology of Galaxy Formation Within the ``Cosmic Web''
Award.AbstractNarration: The Keck Baryonic Structure Survey (KBSS) is a unique study of the distant universe with intensive focus on the peak era of galaxy growth that occurred 10-12 billion years ago, over the cosmological redshift range from 2 to 3. KBSS measures the masess, star formation rates, stellar populations, chemistry, and gas flows in forming galaxies and the intergalactic gas surrounding them. The interface between the two, the circumgalactic medium (CGM), is the region where feedback processes will produce measureable response due to injected energy, momentum, gas, and metals. The Principal Investigator and collaborators have previously obtained extensive optical spectroscopic data on approximately 2300 galaxies in the survey fields, each of which is centered on a hyperluminous quasar. They now propose to observe these same fields with the new, NSF-funded, Multi-Object Spectrometer for Infra-Red Exploration (MOSFIRE), which their team designed and built for the Keck I telescope. With the new data, the team plans to obtain vastly improved measurements of redshift and gas kinematics for a wider range of galaxy types than previously probed, measurements of star formation rates and dust attenuation (extinction), and elemental abundances and physical conditions in the interstellar and circumgalactic media. The PI, as Project Scientist for MOSFIRE, and graduate students supported by this project will work to assist the broader astronomical community in using the instrument. The graduate students will also lead an astronomy outreach program, working with the Pasadena Unified School District to bring their enthusiasm and knowledge into 5th-8th grade classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The most detailed map of the young universe -- a snapshot in time, centered some 11 billion years ago-- has been completed as part of the ``Keck Baryonic Structure Survey''.  For the first time, the map includes not just the locations of the galaxies themselves, found because of the huge energy release as new stars form,  but also the ``web'' of invisible material in between the galaxies that traces the underlying framework on which structure in the universe is built. Violent processes inside galaxies -- dominated by stellar explosions atthat occur at the end of the lifetimes of the most massive new stars --  are so powerful that they come close to blowing apart their own galactic birthplace. Using special observational techniques and large ground-based telescopes, the maps made reveal the locations of raidly-forming galaxies, but also trace the ``blast areas'' -- more than 1000 times large in volume-- affected by the powerful blast waves. The detritus of this process -- the gas and dust blasted into intergalactic space, eventually gets recycled, becoming the fuel for star formation yet to come.  
The information gathered in the process of mapping out a small piece of the universe as it was 11 billion years ago is detailed enough that individual galaxies -- with masses similar to our own Milky Way -- can be weighed and measured as part of establishing their population demographics. It is in some ways rather like paleontology (the study of ancient creatures who walked the earth in the past) - except rather than having to reconstruct the past by recovering fossils and bone fragments, one instead can observe the "dinosaurs" as they walked the earth, directly witnessing the entire ecological system as it happened. As it would do for paleontologists, this type of real-time movie provides a vivid picture of what the universe looked like at a particularly important time in cosmic history, providing insight into how and why it evolved over the intervening millenia to become what we see today
